title: Land Feature Catalog Template
description: Catalogs a single land feature -- mountain range, volcano, forest, river, lake, desert, wetland, or grassland. Mountains should be placed first because they determine rain shadows, which determine where forests, deserts, and rivers form.

id.description: Unique identifier for this land feature (auto-generated)

subtype.description: More specific classification (e.g., for mountains: 'coastal' or 'interior'; for forests: 'temperate' or 'boreal'; for deserts: 'hot', 'cold', 'mild', 'sand', 'rocky')

location.description: Where this feature is located on the continent

continent_id.description: Which continent this feature is on

climate_zone.description: Which climate zone this feature falls in

size.description: Approximate size (length, area, height as appropriate)

height_range.description: For mountains: height range in feet/meters. 3-4000 ft may not cause rain shadows; 10,000+ ft causes oxygen deprivation

rain_shadow_direction.description: For mountains: which direction the rain shadow falls (determined by prevailing winds)

tree_types.description: For forests: evergreen, coniferous, deciduous, or mixed

canopy_density.description: For forests: percentage of canopy coverage (woodland ~30-60%, forest ~60-100%, rainforest near 100%). Denser canopy blocks sunlight and reduces underbrush.

underbrush_density.description: For forests: density of ground-level vegetation. Rainforests have very little underbrush (canopy blocks light), woodlands have sparse underbrush, jungles have impenetrable underbrush. Affects travel difficulty, ambush opportunities, and ability to ride mounts through the area.

surface_type.description: 80% of real deserts are rocky, not sandy

cause.description: What causes this desert (rain shadow from which range, latitude, elevation)

wetland_type.description: Specific type: bogs form in depressions with acidic peat water; fens are grass-covered meadow-like mires fed by ground water; marshes form along slow rivers with grasses and reeds; swamps are wetland forests near large rivers/lakes

water_source.description: Primary water source. Bogs rely on rainfall; fens on groundwater; marshes and swamps on surface water.

water_type.description: Type of water in the wetland

products.description: Products sourced from this wetland (e.g., peat for fuel, rice, honey, sugar, natural medicines, dyes, textiles, fish)

wetland_characteristics.description: For wetlands (bog, fen, marsh, swamp): specific characteristics including type, water source, and products

mountain_formation.description: For mountains: the geological process that formed them. Tectonic convergent boundaries create the tallest ranges; volcanic hotspots create standalone peaks (potentially enormous like Olympus Mons on Mars); glacial processes create cirques, glacial horns, and parallel valleys.

sub_ranges.description: For mountain ranges: regional sub-ranges within a larger range. A long range (1000+ miles) is likely multiple sub-ranges with different names, separated by passes or offsets (e.g., the Blue Ridge and White Mountains are sub-ranges of the Appalachians).

description.description: A narrative description of this feature suitable for storytelling

connected_features.description: Other land features connected to this one (e.g., a river flowing from these mountains)

species_found.description: Species that inhabit this land feature

creatures_found.description: Monsters, animals, or other creatures found here

settlements_nearby.description: Settlements near or on this feature

sovereign_powers_nearby.description: Sovereign powers that control or border this feature

travel_difficulty.description: How difficult it is to traverse this feature

notable_passes_or_routes.description: For mountains: notable passes. For forests/deserts: known routes through

resources.description: Natural resources found here (minerals, timber, herbs, water)

dangers.description: Known dangers (monsters, natural hazards, hostile species)

cultivation_impact.description: How sentient species have altered this feature (deforestation, dams, mining, pollution)

x-cross-references.continent-profile: This feature is located on a continent
x-cross-references.climate-zone-reference: This feature exists within a climate zone
x-cross-references.species-profile: Species inhabiting this feature are defined in Species Profiles
x-cross-references.settlement-profile: Nearby settlements are defined in Settlement Profiles
x-cross-references.sovereign-power-profile: Controlling powers are defined in Sovereign Power Profiles
x-cross-references.land-travel-calculator: Travel through this feature uses the Land Travel Calculator
